title.narrative: Hands Off II Sex work Botswana

description.narrative: Hands Off II partners work to reduce violence against sex workers at community, national and regional level. Outcomes BONELA and Sisonke work on mainly include: an empowered and resilient sex worker movement demands its rights; increased access to and use of inclusive services for sex workers; and a more enabling and supportive environment for sex work.

Sex work in Botswana is conducted in a wide range of locations: from outdoor and street based sex work to restaurants, truck stops, bars, hotels, private homes or hostels. With the closing down of mines the locations where sex work takes place continue to move. There are an estimated 6.700 sex workers in Botswana. Due to the illegal status of sex work, sex workers experience difficulties in accessing health, social services and in seeking justice and legal compensation.

The programme’s primary target group is female, male and transgender sex workers, meaning those who receive money or goods in exchange for sexual services, either regularly or occasionally. INERELA+ will also work with lawyers, government officials, policymakers and service providers.

To reduce violence against sex workers, Aidsfonds works together with Sisonke (sex worker-led organisation from Gaborone and BONELA (a national NGO). Paralegals will continue to support sex workers in accessing legal services. At safe spaces in four districts sex workers can access support groups, receive psychosocial support and health services. Human rights violations against sex workers will be documented and used for lobbying and advocacy purposes. The organisations will advocate for policy and service provision changes at district level, as well as during high level meetings. Relationships with key stakeholders, such as service providers, community and religious leaders and police officers will be sought or intensified to reduce stigma and discrimination.

sector.narrative: Hands Off II Sex work Botswana Human rights
Hands Off II Sex work Botswana Reproductive health care
Hands Off II Sex work Botswana STD control including HIV/AIDS
Hands Off II Sex work Botswana Social mitigation of HIV/AIDS

title.narrative: Long term outcome 1.2

description.narrative: A national sex worker movements is functional and sustainable

title.narrative: Sex workers across the country report to be affiliated with a strong functional and sustainable national movement

description.narrative: To identify the common understanding of profession and rights across sex workers as well as monitor how sex workers inspire, inform and motivate each other.

comment.narrative: There has been constant engagement amongst sex workers within their whats app support groups where they motivate each other.

title.narrative: Long term outcome 4.2

description.narrative: Empowered police officers have improved behaviour towards SWs and KPs

title.narrative: Number of police officers trained in the dignity, diversity and policing training

description.narrative: Number of police officers trained in the dignity, diversity and policing training (female)

comment.narrative: We are yet to conduct these engagements, however Station Commanders in sites of implementation have been engaged and have pledged their support to the program.

title.narrative: Long term outcome 4.3

description.narrative: Empowered police officers have improved behaviour towards SWs and KPs

title.narrative: Relationship building and collaboration results in improved police policy, training programmes and (standard operating) procedures tailored towards sex workers' and key populations' rights

description.narrative: To assess the extent into which interventions under the programme result in structural reforms in police services. This indicator measures the level of commitment of the police to change policy and (standard operating) procedures with regards to the inclusion of the rights of sex workers and other key populations.

comment.narrative: We have built good relations with a few Police Stations, but more needs to be done.

title.narrative: Long term outcome 4.2

description.narrative: Empowered police officers have improved behaviour towards SWs and KPs

title.narrative: Self-reported changes in knowledge, attitude and behaviour towards sex workers by the police

description.narrative: To identify if police sensitisation and engagement leads to improved practice and attitude of police officers towards sex workers (female sex workers, male sex workers and transgender sex workers) and other key populations.

comment.narrative: We are yet to engage with the rest of the police officer.

title.narrative: Overall programme long term outcome 2

description.narrative: Increased access to, and use of inclusive services for seks workers

title.narrative: Sex workers report to have access to quality sex worker-friendly services

description.narrative: To assess if sex workers are satisfied with the services provided to them and if those services are in line with (inter)national standards based on the needs of sex workers. These needs can be different for female sex workers, male sex workers and transgender sex workers. This indicator covers health services, psychosocial services and legal and justice services for all sex workers.

comment.narrative: Sex workers are aware of where to find services friendly to their needs

title.narrative: Long term outcome 3.1

description.narrative: Policies and laws are supportive of the wellbeing of sex workers

title.narrative: Number of national/regional/global level groups and committees in which sex workers are represented

description.narrative: Number of national/regional/global level groups and committees in which sex workers are represented

comment.narrative: These are; Stigma Index Technical Woring Group, Key Populations Technical Working Group;Condom Programming Technical Working Group;S exual Reproductive and Health Rights working group ; Technical Advisory Committee;Country Coordinating Mechanism.

title.narrative: Long term outcome 3.1

description.narrative: Policies and laws are supportive of the wellbeing of sex workers

title.narrative: Campaigns or lobby results in a positive shift in practice under (existing) law, guidelines, and (health) policies and practices supportive of sex workers' rights

description.narrative: To assess the impact of lobby and advocacy programme activities on the environment for sex work. This includes monitoring a shift in practice both with positive and negative outcomes. Improved practice refers to policies and laws supportive of the wellbeing and rights of sex workers, regardless of their gender.

comment.narrative: There has been more collaborative work done to support sex worker needs especially during the current COVID 19 State of Emergency. More needs to be done to kick start the process of changing the law.

title.narrative: Self-reported changes in knowledge, attitude and behaviour towards sex workers by community leaders

description.narrative: To identify if community leader sensitisation and engagement leads to improved attitude of community leaders (traditional and religious leaders) towards sex workers and other key populations, regardless of their gender.

comment.narrative: We are yet to actively engage with community leaders as planned.

title.narrative: Overall objective

description.narrative: Reduced violence against sex workers at community, national & regional level

title.narrative: Number of sex workers reached by communities and networks with SRHR and HIV/AIDS information

description.narrative: Number of sex workers reached by communities and networks with SRHR and HIV/AIDS information (female) until 24 years

comment.narrative: Male sex workers are yet to be identified. We believe the hot spot mapping exercise that will be done this year will assist us in identifying them. Furthermore we hope to recruit one to be a peer outreach worker.

Male sex workers are yet to be identified. We believe the hot spot mapping exercise that will be done this year will assist us in identifying them. Furthermore we hope to recruit one to be a peer outreach worker.
These were reached during a collaboration with Success Capital, where we have developed a documentary about the plight of sex workers what can be done to mitigate their challenges
These(1700) were reached through IT plartforms through the year and the 80 were reached through quarterly human rights discussions

Transgender sex workers are yet to be identified. We believe the hot spot mapping exercise that will be done this year will assist us in identifying them. Furthermore we hope to recruit one to be a peer outreach worker.

We managed to engage with only 4 more younger sex workers on top of those we had made contact with. We believe we will reach out to more through the expansion of our reach into 2 more districts-Kang and Mahalapye

description.narrative: Safe sex work locations with increased respectful interaction between police and sex workers

title.narrative: Number of human rights violations reported to the police

description.narrative: Number of human rights violations reported to the police

comment.narrative: The Police have registered all these cases with one griveous bodily harm case closed with the sentensing of the perpetrator to 7 years in Prison.

title.narrative: Long term outcome 4.1

description.narrative: Safe sex work locations with increased respectful interaction between police and sex workers

title.narrative: Sex workers report changes in police behaviour

description.narrative: To identify if sex workers experience less violence and stigma and discrimination by police officers. This includes a measurement of increased confidence to report cases to the police and satisfaction with police service. Because the experience with police can significantly differ depending on gender of the sex worker, this outcome indicator will look at gender disaggregation.

comment.narrative: Sex workers are more confident and are not ashamed of being sex workers.

title.narrative: Long term outcome 1.3

description.narrative: Sex workers with strong rights-awareness are united

title.narrative: Human rights training results in a united sex worker movement aware of their rights

description.narrative: To assess if there is a strong inclusive sex worker movement able to demand their rights, reaching female sex workers, male sex workers and transgender sex workers. Demanding their rights includes the right to health, peaceful assembly and association and dignity and lives free from violence, discrimination and stigma.

comment.narrative: There are active sex worker support groups that are actively engaged in seeking better health care services.

title.narrative: Long term outcome 3.2

description.narrative: Stigma and discrimination against sex workers is reduced

title.narrative: Number of community leaders trained on the rights of sex workers

description.narrative: Number of community leaders trained on the rights of sex workers

comment.narrative: We are yet to conduct these engagements

title.narrative: Long term outcome 3.2

description.narrative: Stigma and discrimination against sex workers is reduced

title.narrative: Sex workers report a reduction in experienced stigma and discrimination by their community and by society

description.narrative: To identify a change in communities and society's perspective on sex work contributing to a more supportive environment for sex work. This indicator refers to stigma and discrimination in relation to sex workers HIV status and/or gender/sexuality/profession and includes self-stigma.

comment.narrative: We are yet to measure this, however community interactions and comments during radio shows a slight shift in attitudes.
